Dwelling in Second Life? A phenomenological evaluation of online virtual worlds

Dwelling in Second Life? A phenomenological evaluation of online virtual worlds

  • Chris Houliez1 &
  • Edward Gamble2 

Virtual Reality volume 17, pages263–278(2013)Cite this article

  • 869 Accesses

  • 4 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

In previous research on virtual worlds, the question of whether virtual space can be evaluated just like “real world” space has not been fully addressed. This paper challenges the perceived commonsensical set of assumptions through which virtual world activities are usually unpacked and proposes a new method of evaluating virtual worlds based on Martin Heidegger’s phenomenology. Various focus groups conducted in the virtual world Second Life confirmed that a phenomenological paradigm is more appropriate to fully make sense of and leverage this new medium. Besides questioning the relevancy of dealing with virtual worlds as if they were parallel spaces, this paper, by leveraging a new conceptualization of virtual worlds, also offers suggestions for new online qualitative methodologies.

Introduction

Over the past few years, online virtual worlds have attracted a growing number of users. One such virtual world, Second Life, is a platform that may offer a glimpse at what may become the 3D Internet of the future. Second Life has attracted some significant corporate presence, with companies such as Adidas, Coca Cola, and IBM investing in virtual stores, headquarters, and virtual meeting places. Even though some Second Life users have criticized the “marketization” of this new online medium, the business-friendly atmosphere of Second Life is evident in the market processes that make the creation, sales, and acquisition of items rather efficient (e.g., existence of a virtual currency called the “Linden dollar”).

The perceptual similarities between virtual and “real world” activities (e.g., the three-dimensionality of the encountered space) are such that some have advised researchers to treat Second Life’s 3D avatars as actual persons, with actual wants, needs, and desires (e.g., Hemp 2006). The brand name “Second Life” itself illustrates the assumed similarities between the users’ first life in the “real world” and their avatar-mediated activities in a virtual world. On this very issue, Zahorik and Jenison (1998) noted that “The term virtual reality serves as an additional clue to a rationalistic orientation [of the current view on virtual worlds]: the existence of a virtual reality seems to tacitly assume that the existence of ‘real reality’ is unimpeachable.”

As a direct consequence, it has become common practice to conduct research in online virtual environments as if they were parallel worlds (e.g., Turney and Pocknee 2005; Murray 2006; Stewart et al. 2007). Conducting focus groups “in-world” (as the users of Second Life would say), instead of in a physical, “real world” setting offers various advantages: In Second Life, compensations given to focus group participants rarely exceed L$3,000 (less than US$10) per hour; and being able to conduct online focus groups in a 3D environment significantly cuts both travel time and expenses. Despite those genuine upsides to doing research in Second Life, it might be problematic to expeditiously draw a paradigmatic parallel between online virtual worlds and the “real world” and to assume that traditional focus group methodologies can be applied “as is” to a new medium: current ontological, epistemological, and methodological approaches relevant to a nontechnical environment might not fit the specificities of a new medium such as a virtual world.

As online 3D space is hard to decipher and conceptualize, some researchers have resorted to neologisms, such as Levy’s “space of knowledge” (Levy 1994), Mitropoulos’ (2003) “electronic space,” or Castells’ “crystallized space” (Castells 1997), to define the virtual world experience. Others have advocated “a fundamental and profound revision of our current worldview” (Doueihi 2008). However, none has identified yet a paradigm that would better answer the ontological challenges posed by virtual worlds. The objective of this paper is to unpack the commonsensical paradigm through which researchers currently evaluate virtual worlds and to propose instead a phenomenological framework—the advantages of which will be discussed.

The remainder of this article proceeds as follows. After introducing the concept of online virtual worlds, a review of qualitative research conducted in those media will ensue. In the subsequent section, the authors will discuss the Cartesian meta-assumptions framing our usual conceptualization of online virtual worlds, before offering an alternative research paradigm (based on Heidegger’s work) that can be applied to an online virtual world context. The concept of “presence” will then be discussed and interpreted through a Cartesianist lens, then a phenomenological one. The methodology of the fieldwork conducted in Second Life will then be described, before a preliminary analysis of those focus groups is proposed. Finally, the discussion and conclusion section will focus on the potential benefits of the proposed paradigmatic shift, as well as the limitations of this research.

Online virtual worlds: a review

Online virtual worlds

Online virtual worlds are Massively Multiplayer Online Role Playing Games (MMORPG) replicating a three-dimensional space, in which a user is represented by a 3D avatar. Users can navigate through virtual space via their avatar and meet other in-world users whose avatars are exploring the same virtual space at the same time. Those virtual worlds are called “persistent,” because they remain in place even when a user disconnects from the software running the game on his computer (technically speaking, the virtual landscape that can be explored is permanently stored on the service provider’s servers). There are two categories of online virtual worlds: game-oriented virtual worlds, in which users are expected to follow some specific rules to climb in the game’s hierarchy (e.g., World of Warcraft), and freeform virtual worlds, in which users do not have predetermined goals to take into consideration, and where they can create 3D objects, avatar forms, or virtual clothing of their choosing. Freeform games bear many similarities with economies that operate in the “real world.” For instance, in Second Life, there are many design and infrastructure support functions offered that help stimulate creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship. Various businesses currently operating in “real world” marketplaces have heralded Second Life as the newest channel for brand building (Barnes and Mattsson 2008, 2011). Some Fortune 500 employers resorted to Second Life to deal with the orientation, engagement, and training of employees (Arnold 2009). As an illustration, IBM has used this new medium extensively to organize in-world conferences, which allowed the company to foster collaboration between IBM employees from different countries at a fraction of the cost of a “real world” conference (Ringo 2007). Another Fortune 500 example is that of Proctor and Gamble, who leveraged virtual platforms for product concept testing (WARC 2010). From an educational standpoint, over 170 accredited educational institutions are operating in Second Life (Jennings and Collins 2007). Harvard, INSEAD, and many other universities have started a process of developing a virtual world for their students as a tool to foster learning (Foster 2007; Kopp and Burkle 2010; Ward 2010). Other universities have used Second Life as a cost-effective simulation of the real marketplace (e.g., asking business students to generate revenue through the in-world economy by leveraging “real world” business theories and principles—Wagner 2008). Even though the popularity of Second Life has reached a plateau in recent years, the fact that its software, OpenSim, became open-source in 2007 is important to note, as it led to the creation of dozens of other online virtual worlds (e.g., OSGrid, MyOpenGrid, or Meta7). With a global economy exceeding $6B (Castronova 2010) and over 300+ virtual worlds (Cyber Creatives Inc. 2011a, b), it would be remiss to render these platforms a whim rather than transformational technologies (Wasko et al. 2011).

Qualitative research conducted in virtual worlds

Hine notes that, if contrary to previous doubts, “effective qualitative research relationships can be forged online, it does not come without challenges or limitations” (Hine 2005, p. 19). This is also true in an online virtual world. For any qualitative researcher striving to collect in-depth qualitative data in-world, a major methodological issue stems from the fact that an avatar’s owner remains invisible, “hidden” behind one’s keyboard. While some research questions can be answered within the virtual world through avatar-to-avatar interactions, others would require moving research relationships from an online to an offline context. However, few Second Life users are willing to disclose, while in-world, their real identity, making the gathering of rich data a real challenge. Anthropologist Tom Boellstorff had to face this very issue during his fieldwork in a virtual world: “my fundamental methodological conceit was to conduct research entirely inside Second Life. However, I soon recognized [during the fieldwork] that for many residents, entirely inside Second Life included participation in a range of websites external to the Second Life program” (Boellstorff 2008, p. 198).

Despite those limitations, some researchers managed to successfully conduct research entirely in Second Life. For instance, via research conducted in Second Life, Moon and Kim (2001) were able to extend and empirically validate the Technology Acceptance Model in a 3D Internet context. Guo and Barnes (2009) also successfully conducted in-world focus groups, with 24 participants selected according to demographic and experiential characteristics (the objective was to better understand factors influencing purchase behavior in virtual worlds). However, as acknowledged by the authors, more that focus groups per se, those were “group interviews (…) selected and assembled by researchers to discuss and comment on, from personal experience, the topic that is the subject of the research” (p. 80). In the same vein, Parmentier and Rolland (2009) recognize that, in an online 3D context, “the absence of paraverbal dimensions (e.g., intonation and accentuation) and nonverbal dimensions (gestures, facial expressions, or distance between speakers) can work against the researcher during the interview in terms of message interpretation. He or she has only the basis of the conversation’s rhythm, emoticons, style changes, and text content on which to carry out the interview” (Parmentier and Rolland 2009, p. 48).

As a result, can those in-world focus groups still be called focus groups? Some believe so, as the level of anonymity preserved in a virtual world context also has its advantages (Galloway 2011). Broitman (2007) mentions that “an online 3D focus experience provides a natural setting, where consumers can speak with a greater degree of candor [than in a ‘real world’ context]; there is a greater visceral connection between people in virtual worlds than through other forms of interactive media such as the telephone or the 2D web.” However, other researchers have found it difficult to stay on-topic in a virtual world environment where the 3D avatars can easily teleport themselves in and out of the focus group room (Schmeil et al. 2009). On a more positive note, the same researchers’ experience in Second Life led to the belief that 3D “community virtual chats” as they call them, when compared with regular, “2D” text exchanges, improve the participants’ self-presentation, as the context in which the exchanges take place is visually much richer.

What is common to all the above-mentioned attempts at conducting qualitative research is Second Life is the unchallenged belief that the online 3D medium, with its human-looking avatars and artificial landscapes, can be used as an ersatz of the so-called real world. A potential issue, it seems, is that this very notion of a “real world” has not been questioned from an epistemological point of view by those who have conducted qualitative research in-world. In the next section, we will review the Cartesian meta-assumptions implicitly framing the current discourse on virtual worlds, before introducing Heidegger’s phenomenology. To help in the discussion, Table 1 lists the meta-assumptions underlying Cartesianism and Heideggerian phenomenology.

Cartesianism and phenomenology: a review

Cartesianism: a review

Cartesianism upholds a metaphysical dualism made of two finite substances: matter and mind. Matter—which Descartes calls res extensa—comprises everything but a person’s own awareness of being. Complementing res extensa is res cogitans, also referred to as “mind” or “the Ego.” Res cogitans is a substance in its own right, our “thinking substance” (Descartes 1951). Mind “has need of no place, nor is dependent on any material thing” (Descartes 1951, p. 98). In his second meditations, Descartes defines more precisely his theory—We only have access to the world of our ideas: things in the world are only accessed indirectly; ideas and the things they represent are separate from each other; these represented things are “external” to the mind (i.e., from a different substance); and it is possible for these ideas to constitute either accurate or false representations (e.g., a mirage). Regarding this latter point, as neither our senses nor our thoughts are error-proof, we can only infer what the world—that is, an assumed transcendental reality—resembles, and forever, the “real world” remains outside our awareness: Our bodily sensations always mediate the “real world.” The Cartesianist worldview is perhaps best summarized by Winograd and Flores (1986): “(1) We are inhabitants of a ‘real world’ made up of objects bearing properties, and our actions take place in that world; (2) there are ‘objective facts’ about that world that do not depend on the integration or the presence of any person [i.e., the world is ‘persistent,’ the same way one can say that Second Life is persistent, as the 3D grid remains stored on servers even when no Second Life users are logged in]; and (3) thoughts and intentions about action can somehow cause physical (hence real world) motion in our bodies.”

Despite the fact that a Cartesianist interpretation of other emerging technologies has proven to be challenging if not impossible (this will be discussed at length in the section on Phenomenology), online virtual worlds often are conceptualized and evaluated through a dualistic perspective: As the online, server-located 3D grid fits the definition of a Cartesian res extensa, that is, an empty and persistent three-dimensional space filled with objects, it is hardly surprising that fifty percent of Second Life’s users wish they could “upload their mind [i.e., their res cognitans] into Second Life if this was technically possible” (Au 2008). Such a Cartesian interpretation of online 3D space results in researchers blindly applying “real world” qualitative methodologies (e.g., focus groups) to a virtual world context: The persistent 3D grid is conceived of as a spatially extended physical out-thereness parallel to the one we are accustomed to; and the avatars are dealt with as if they were “little people” owning their own mind.

Phenomenology: a review

Phenomenology attempts to discover the inherent essence of appearances, where an appearance is described as anything of which one is conscious. With phenomenology, the focus is on the conscious experience as lived from a subjective, first-person point of view. During the Husserlian reduction (Husserl 1913), the person withholds judgment concerning the world—and one’s involvement in it. The person stops presuming the reality of the world of common sense (i.e., a Cartesian, three-dimensional out-thereness filled with objects), focusing instead on one’s awareness of being.

In lieu of Descartes’ two finite substances, Heidegger envisions three “ways of being.” The first is the way of being of substances or represented objects, such as the color “blue,” or the concept of roundness. This way of being is called “presence-at-hand.” Heidegger’s second “way of being,” called “Existenz,” is the way of being of humans. Human reality, for Heidegger, consists essentially in being a “being-toward,” that is, a being “standing out for its being” (Heidegger 1962) projecting oneself into the world. The peculiarity of Heidegger’s stand on human Existenz is emblematized by the concept of “Dasein,” which literally means “being there.” Dasein is the dimension of the self that makes humans take a stance on their own existence (and taking such stance is, for Heidegger, the “essence of man”). Heidegger coined the term “Care” to define the essential unity that makes the structure of the human being. Care is composed of existentiality (being beyond of oneself, i.e., never simply in the present as such), facticity (being in a particular situation in the world as a result of past actions), and fallenness (being absorbed in the world by virtue of one’s concern for it).

Heidegger’s third way of being is called “readiness-to-hand” and corresponds to the way of being of “equipment” (i.e., any tool for humans to act on the world in which they were “thrown”—Heidegger 1962). Such equipment can range from a hammer to a prosthesis—or even one’s own hand. For Heidegger, being is defined by the way one leverages such equipment to act on the world: “We are that within which we operate, and in such a taken-for-granted way that we forget the state of affair and its basic structure as being the basis of the structure of things.” (Heidegger 1962, p. 25). When equipment truly is “ready-to-hand,” that is, when it works well as a tool for a person to act on the world, its conspicuousness vanishes: “the peculiarity of what is ready-to-hand is that (…) it must withdraw in order to be ready-to-hand quite authentically” (Heidegger 1962, p. 99). Heidegger gives the example of how blind individuals walking down a street not only forget about the constant presence in their hand of the walking cane, but also achieve such a high level of fluidity (“directionality”) between their body and the cane that they have the feeling of “seeing” through the cane. In this instance, the cane, due to its “readiness-to-hand,” becomes as inconspicuous as a limb. It is only if the cane breaks or falls from its user’s hand that it will be recognized as an external object, an “unreadiness-to-hand” that has ceased to be lined up with its owner’s current mode of coping with the world (i.e., walking down a street). In such case, a “break-down” has occurred, and the cane, instead of being a “ready-to-hand,” becomes a “present-at-hand”; that is, a nontransparent object detached from our way of being-in-the-world. Lined up equipment forms what Heidegger refers as “regions” (gegends in German), that is, referential systems for our everyday spatial practices. A kitchen, with its various utensils lined up in different ways to facilitate various tasks (e.g., cooking, eating, dishwashing), is sometimes used as the example of a Heideggerian region. The inter-referring nature of Heidegger’s regions finds its origin in Heidegger’s belief that objects only have a meaning in virtue of their being set in a “referential whole,” that is, a matrix of inter-referring equipments determined by the concern over the world (i.e., Care) on the part of a person. As an illustration, a utensil as mundane as a hammer could not be understood without making reference to nails, objects to be nailed, houses to build, etc. Without such “referential whole,” that is, if we do not take into account the preexisting intertextuality between utensils—and our intrinsic familiarity with it—a hammer would not be a hammer, as it would be dissociated from the holistic context making it a potential ready-to-hand. Hence, for phenomenology, equipments cannot be objectified via a scientific reduction isolating them from the rest of the world: Their existence as phenomena intrinsically originates from our implicit familiarity with the world, the intrinsic understanding of a “referential whole” within which we have come to exist. This unconscious and implicit familiarity of Dasein with this referential whole or “matrix of significance” (Molina 1962) is what Heidegger refers to as “the worldliness of the world” (Heidegger 1962).

“Being There”

Being in a particular situation in the world, or “being-in-the-world” as Heidegger would say, does not mean to be physically contained in the universe. The world in the hyphenated expression “being-in-the-world” is not the world of separate objects that would be located in a 3D out-thereness. Rather, the world is an aspect of the human being itself: It is the previously mentioned matrix of significance determined by Dasein’s concern over the world.

The manner in which Dasein is “in” the world can, for Heidegger, be described through the notions of “self-encountering” and “understanding”: Dasein encounters itself as being located there, that is, in a specific set of gegends. This state of being at a given place, yet without knowing why this place and not another, is called “throwness” by Heidegger. Dasein is thrown with neither prior knowledge nor individual option into a world (Steiner 1978). One can say that throwness, along with the “facticity” resulting from it, is the there of Dasein.

The second notion that helps understand Dasein’s way of a “being-in-the-world” is “understanding,” which refers to Dasein’s ability to be concerned with its own possibilities as a power-to-be, as a being-toward, that is, as a source of possible actions. When such understanding is lacking, for Heidegger, our being-in-the-world is inauthentic: It is not under our control (for instance, when one person becomes too absorbed in daily routines), and Dasein ends up acting as one usually does in a similar situation. This results in the concealment of the person’s authentic possibilities from oneself. For Heidegger, only a mood (i.e., a specific set of attunement with the world in which it has been thrown) that he calls “dread” can rescue Dasein from inauthenticity: Dread opens up to the person the opportunity to freely exercise its power-to-be on the world in which it was thrown. It also allows Dasein to “dwell”: Heidegger insists that one dwells when one is at peace with the experienced space; when one can be oneself, be authentic in that place.

Heidegger’s spatiality

When he uses the word “spatiality,” Heidegger does not allude to “being there” in a given physical place, but rather to Dasein’s mode of dealing with the two other types of “being” (beside Dasein). Quoting Heidegger: “When we speak of man and space, it sounds as though man stood on one side, space on the other. Yet, space is not something that faces man” (Heidegger 1971). The main two features of Heideggerian spatiality are “de-severing” and “directionality.” De-severing is the basic capacity that Dasein has to get near to unreadiness-to-hand, that is, to get the ultimate grip on equipment. Heidegger explains that “de-severing’ equals to making the farness vanish, that is, bringing it close” (Heidegger 1962, p. 109). Again, notions of “nearness” and “farness” are not to be understood here in their usual meaning—For Heidegger, physical distance always remains a subjective matter: only “what is ready-to-hand in our everyday life has the character of closeness” (Heidegger 1962, p. 135). The business of getting things close is about opening up space for Dasein to act on the world via equipment. “Directionality,” in the Heideggerian terminology, refers to how equipment lines up in order for Dasein to engage in specific spatial practices. “Equipment has its place, otherwise it lies around (…) This place defines itself as one place, out of a whole totality of places, directionally lined up with each other and belonging to the context of equipment available as ready-to-hand” (Heidegger 1962, p. 135).

Heidegger and technology

For Heidegger, technology, or rather what he refers to as Techne, “reveals whatever does not bring itself forth and does not yet lie here before us” (Heidegger 1977, p. 13). That is, Techne is one way through which the far can become near though de-severing. Techne is “intentional action that constitutes a gap between the world as it was before the action, and the new world it calls into being.” (Boellstorff 2008, p. 55). Techne, by revealing the “unready-to-hand,” unconceals beings: For instance, “once the stone-age humans discovered the techniques to extract iron from rocks, they were not just ‘rocks’, they became seen as possibilities for making iron tools” (Introna 2002, p. 222).

The evolution of artificial intelligence (A.I.) over the past four decades provides an illustration of the challenges and frustrations associated with adopting (and attempting to replicate via technologies) a Cartesianist worldview. The predominance of a Cartesianist worldview has been denounced by various researchers (e.g., Dreyfus 1991; Searle 1989; Zahorik and Jenison 1998), who pointed to the fact that there is a “residual dualism present in rationalistic approaches to artificial intelligence and cognitive psychology” (Zahorik and Jenison 1998). Dreyfus (e.g., 1972, 1991, 1993) has written extensively on the impossibility for an A.I. system to encode the entire set of objects and inter-referring relations composing the world as we experience it. The root problem, as Dreyfus sees it, is the presupposition made by the A.I. community that we all have a mental model of the world in our mind and that such model, if encoded, could help replicate human knowledge and behaviors. However, for Dreyfus—a phenomenologist—“there is usually no need for a representation of the world in our mind since the best way to find out the current state of affairs is to look to the world as we experience it” (Dreyfus 1993, p. 112). In addition, Dreyfus argues that a computer—lacking the innate familiarity with the Heideggerian “worldiness of the world” defining the human experience—will be unable to capture the inter-referring nature of any phenomenon. Hence, for Dreyfus, it is not possible for representations to fully characterize the human experience.

The challenges of conceptualizing “presence” and online virtual worlds

Even before the emergence of online virtual worlds, some researchers had noticed that Information Technology challenged our commonsensical, Cartesian sense of embodiment and space. For instance, for Hayles (1999, p. 27), “merely communicating via email already problematizes thinking of the body as a self-evident physicality,” because it allows us to act outside of a commonsensical sphere of actions governed by the physical body. And indeed, research has shown that 69 % of the users of text-based virtual environments (called multi-user dungeon dimensions or MUDs), despite the poor sensory quality of MUDs, feel a sense of presence within this type of medium (Towell and Towell 1997). In the same vein, Haraway (1991) commented that “it is not clear what is mind and what is body in machines that resolve into coding practices.”

Even though the ubiquitous aspect of Information Technology was salient before the apparition of online virtual worlds, “the arcane and somewhat philosophical concept of presence became more theoretically urgent with the arrival of immersive virtual reality” (Biocca 1997, p. 128). Biocca notes that, in online virtual worlds, “observing the day-to-day movements of our consciousness between the experience of our unmediated body and our mediated virtual bodies, we may come to ask: Where am ‘I’ present?” (Biocca 1997, p. 140). The feeling of presence felt when evolving within a virtual world has even become, for people using virtual worlds—who, not incidentally, call themselves “residents” and not “users”—an intrinsic part of the virtual world experience—Weckström (2004) for instance believes that a virtual world has to support the following factors: the environment has to be persistent, it has to support interaction, there has to be a representation of the user (i.e., an avatar), it must offer the user the possibility to choose from a multitude of things to do, and there has to be a feeling of presence. This does not come as a surprise if we agree with Steuer (1995) that “the difference between virtual reality and other media [is] in a difference in the level of presence.”

Defining presence and telepresence

Evaluating the experiences within virtual worlds requires insights into the notion of “presence” (Lee 2004). Presence has been associated with our concept of reality—this includes our interaction with objects, people, and our perception of ourselves (Mantovani and Giuseppe 1999; Lee 2004). Researchers have identified the need for “presence” to be further understood (Biocca and Delaney 1995; Held and Durlach 1992) in order to develop a broader theory, including criteria and scope conditions (Biocca and Burgoon 2003). The term “telepresence” was coined by Artificial Intelligence MIT scientist Minsky (Minsky 1980). According to the International Society for Presence Research (ISPR), “Presence (a shortened version of the term ‘telepresence’) is a psychological state or subjective perception in which, even though part of all of an individual’s current experience is generated by and/or filtered through human-made technology, part or all of the individual’s perception fails to accurately acknowledge the role of the technology in the experience. Except in the most extreme cases, the individual can indicate correctly that s/he is using the technology, but *at some level* and *to some degree*, her/his perceptions overlook that knowledge and objects, events, entities, and environments are perceived as if the technology was not involved in the experience” (ISPR 2000). Telepresence has been linked to the “amount of sensory information” transmitted through the technology interface (Sheridan 1992). It has been shown that an enhanced sense of presence is at the core of the virtual experience and is implicit in users’ evaluation and satisfaction of virtual environments (Lombard and Ditton 1997). Telepresence has been associated with other technologies than virtual reality, and the extent to which it is felt in other media such as the telephone or emails has been the object of previous investigations (e.g., Short et al. 1976; Rice 1993). It should be noted that telepresence is not an all-or-nothing phenomenon, but rather follows a continuum (IJsellsteijn 2002). As “telepresence” and “presence” are used interchangeably by most researchers (including in ISPR’s above definition), from now on, only the word “presence” will be used, unless it is mentioned in a quotation.

As mentioned by Slater et al. (2009), “presence is a concept without valid measurement.” Three main measurement approaches can be distinguished: questionnaires (e.g., Witmer and Singer 1998; Lombard et al. 2009), physiological indicators involving the autonomous nervous system activity (e.g., skin conductance), and behavioral observations such as postural responses (e.g., subjects rotating their trunk in yaw while walking through a virtual aperture in Freeman et al. 2000). Spatiotemporal aspects of adaptive behavior, governed by volition and selection, have also been used to measure presence (e.g., Lepecq et al. 2008). Another measurement of presence, the “temple Presence Inventory” (Lombard et al. 2009), is based on eight orthogonal factors: (1) spatial presence (e.g., presence as transportation, or having the feeling of objects present in the medium can be “touched”); (2) social presence as an actor (perception that the people “around” can hear/feel the presence of the user within the medium); (3) passive social presence (e.g., being able to observe the facial expression of the other users); (4) active social presence (ability to interact with other users); (5) level of engagement within the medium (extent to which the user feels mentally immersed in the experienced medium); (6) social richness (including the emotional richness of the experience); (7) social realism (likelihood that the events heard/seen in the medium would occur “in the real world”); and (8) perceptual realism of the medium (e.g., how much the heat or coolness of the technology-mediated environment felt like it would have, if the user had experienced it directly). Jones (2007) identifies four factors influencing the feeling of presence: form (the capabilities and limitations of the technology), user (his/her physical and psychological attributes), style (the techniques defining the technology being used, which for instance may foster or hinder continuity in the production of the technology-mediated experience), and content (the subject matter available via the technology). It was shown (Bouvier 2008) that the key for presence to occur is not the realistic aspect of the technology being used (e.g., how “real” a virtual world looks), but rather its level of credibility (where “credibility” is assessed through five “pillars”: the immersive aspect of the technology; its interactive nature; the consistency of the action–perception loop; the emotional richness of the technology-mediated experience; and the extent to which the subject’s five senses are involved in the experience). Also, combining mediated social touch (i.e., interpersonal touch over a distance) with visual feedback increases the user’s sense of presence (Haans and IJsselsteijn 2009). For Slater et al. (2009), there are three necessary conditions for presence: (a) the consistent low latency sensorimotor loop between sensory data and proprioception; (b) statistical plausibility (i.e., images must be statistically plausible in relation to the probability distribution of images over natural scenes; and (c) behavior–response correlation (i.e., correlation between the state and behavior of participants, and responses within the environment). Lastly, it was found that being “embodied” within a virtual reality leads to a greater reported sense of presence, compared to looking down and seeing no part of oneself (Slater and Usoh 1994).

Is “Presence” Cartesianist or Heideggerian?

For some, recent technologies have challenged the concept of presence/absence to the point that it has lost its meanings: Hayles suggests shifting from presence/absence to pattern/randomness, as she believes that both embodiment and communication are now “characterized by their tendencies toward unexpected metamorphoses, attenuations, and dispersions.” (Hayles 1999, p. 30). Biocca (1997) also casts some doubt on the relevance of a commonsensical, Cartesianist approach to the notion of presence: “the engineering and computer science use of the term telepresence, or presence, started as a telecommunication design goal and has evolved into an intriguing theoretical problem and philosophical issue.”

The fact remains though that most definitions of presence imply a Cartesianist worldview, with the existence of a “real” world—of a res extensa. On this, we agree with Zahorik and Jenison (1998): “Current research on presence in virtual reality and teleoperator systems subscribes, in one way or another, to the rationalistic orientation,” as it “points to a clearly rationalistic orientation, specifically that of a subject/object distinction.” For instance, ISPR (2000) mentions that presence can lead a person “to perceive that s/he is in an environment in which objects, events, and people act and/or respond in the way(s) the viewer believes they did or would in the physical world; the user may comment ‘It seemed so realistic!’” The very differentiation made by some researchers between the notions of “presence” and “telepresence” points to the fact that they differentiate from an ontological point of view between the “real world” and technology-mediated events. For example, Sundar et al. (2008a, b) “adopt the more general term presence to indicate a general sense of nonmediation while telepresence refers more specifically to a sense of being in the medium.”

A similar dichotomy, but this time involving the dyad flow/presence instead of presence/telepresence, is found in Weibel et al. (2007). For them, if presence can shortly be described as immersion into a technology-mediated environment, flow rather refers to an experience of immersion into a certain activity. Wirth et al. (2007) too adopt a representational (hence Cartesianist) worldview, when they assert that presence is a two-step process, with the first step consisting in the development of a mental model of the mediated space (the “Spatial Situation Model”). It is also true that some of the results obtained by researchers tend to validate a Cartesianist interpretation of virtual worlds as “parallel words.” For instance, Yee et al. (2007) showed that social norms of gender, interpersonal distance, and eye gaze transfer into virtual worlds (e.g., in-world male–male dyads have larger interpersonal distances than female–female dyads). We also find the object/subject Cartesian dichotomy in the ISPR’s (2000) definition of “engagement,” which is supposed to “occur when part or all of a person’s perception is directed toward objects, events and/or people created by the technology, and away from objects, events, and/or people in the physical world.” However, some of the definitions of “presence” point to a phenomenological aspect of the phenomenon. For instance, Nunez and Blake (2003) and Waterworth and Waterworth (2001) stressed the importance of the medium user’s suspension of belief in triggering a feeling of presence, which is very reminiscent of the previously mentioned Husserlian reduction. This very notion of “suspension in belief” can also be identified in ISPR’s (2000) definition of co-presence: “co-presence occurs when part or all of a person’s perception fails to accurately acknowledge the role of technology in her/his perception that the person or people with whom s/he is engaged in two-way communication is/are in the same physical location and environment.” In addition, Sundar et al. (2008a, b) show that high levels of affordances (i.e., capabilities offered by the medium to facilitate a potential action in this medium—capabilities such as level of interactivity and ease of navigability) led to a greater feeling of presence. That is, affordances, by making of the medium an inconspicuous ready-to-hand, lead to a de-severing of the medium that results in a greater degree of directionality, which itself opens up to the virtual world’s user the opportunity to freely exercise its power-to-be. We find a similar (and implicit) phenomenological definition of presence in Riva (2008), for whom “subjects are ‘present’ if they are able to enact in an external world their intentions (…) the more are the intentional levels supported by a [virtual world], the more is the presence in it.” That is, the more the user can achieve a certain level of directionality, of de-severing in a medium, the more presence will be felt. The importance of achieving readiness-to-hand in a medium to really feel present “there” is also obvious in Slater et al. (2009) description of the factors influencing what they call “correlational presence”: According to their findings, there is a stronger feeling of presence when there is a correlation between our motor actions and the response that we experience. This correlational presence is strengthened when there is a continued, predictable correlation between proprioception and sensory data (e.g., a head-turn must result in a concomitant change in the visual field; or moving up one’s real left arm results in the avatar moving up its left arm in a 3D medium).

There is also an uncanny phenomenological dimension to the concept of “break in presence,” introduced in Slater and Steed (2000): “Presence can be broken by external events or internal mental processes that bring the true nature of the experience to the person’s conscious awareness, at which point presence is reduced or extinguished” (ISPR 2000). In a virtual world, such break in presence (i.e., what a phenomenologist would call “severing”) may occur as a result of a sudden disconnection from the medium, or when lag is experienced in-world. We recognize here the Heideggerian notions of “unreadiness-to-hand” and “break-downs”—Break in presence occurs when the referential system in which a medium’s user acts on the world loses its cohesion: suddenly, the virtual world becomes a nontransparent “present-at-hand.” The virtual world as a tool has not sufficiently “lined up” as equipment for a certain level of directionality to be achieved. According to Garau et al. (2004), breaks in presence can range in intensity, resulting in varying recovery times. And the experience of a break in presence is likened by the subjects to a feeling of “waking up” or a “shock,” with an increase in galvanic skin response (GSR). Slater et al. (2003) add that “breaks in presence are stress-inducing events, since loss of presence in everyday life is something rarely experienced.” We beg do disagree with this latter assertion, as Heidegger’s examples of a blind person losing grip on his cane, or of a person accidentally letting go his hammer, provide us with vivid illustrations of breaks in presence happening in everyday life and without the use of any high-tech medium. However, a phenomenological interpretation of the notion of break in presence can only agree with the assertion that a break-down is stressful: When what is “readiness-to-hand” becomes “present-at-hand,” the person’s absorption in the world (his fallenness) is suddenly interrupted. S/he ceases to be the “being-toward” s/he was prior to the break-down. Prior to concluding this section on a phenomenological interpretation of the notion of presence, it is worth noting that we disagree with Zahorik and Jenison’s (1998) phenomenological definition of presence. They assert that presence is felt only when objects become “present-at-hand”: “reporting a feeling is reporting that which is mentally represented. In order to report mentally represented things, one must step back from the primary mode of existence” (Zahorik and Jenison 1998, p. 85). On the contrary, and based on the previously mentioned findings on presence, we believe that presence occurs only when a region offers enough de-severing for Dasein to experience fallenness and be absorbed in its existentiality. The notion of “present-at-hand,” contrary to what Zahorik and Jenison (1998) seem to believe, has no connection to the notion of “presence.” Talking of a “feeling of presence” can even be considered an oxymoron: When true presence is experience, fallenness is such that Dasein is too absorbed as a being-in-the-world to stand back from the experienced situation and report on it. This explains why most measurements of presence are based on postexperience questionnaires.

The “3Ding” of virtual worlds

If the notion of presence has previously been discussed phenomenologically in the context of new technologies (e.g., Zahorik and Jenison 1998), the 3D aspect of online virtual worlds has never been the object of a phenomenological reduction. What are the decisive criteria that enable us to experience a 3D virtual world as such; and the criteria on the grounds of which we distinguish a 3D virtual world as such? Let us first remind the reader that, in a phenomenological reduction, the aim is to recover the strangeness lost with familiarity, or through empirical reduction. For the Cartesianist, 3D virtual worlds can be scientifically reduced to bits of 0’s and 1’s stored on servers (in the case of Second Life, located somewhere in California). But that is not the way a phenomenological reduction would describe Second Life: The phenomenologist will instead focus on the raw experience offered by online virtual worlds, setting aside any presupposition or objectification. In the case of 3D virtual worlds, a phenomenologist operating a phenomenological reduction could say that 3D does not exist because Second Life is available: The 3Ding of virtual worlds was already pervasive for sites such as Second Life to become possible, in the same manner Introna and Ilharco (2004) could say that, from a phenomenological standpoint, the TV and computer screens we use in our everyday life “screen” because screening was part of our referential whole even prior to the invention of screens. That is, 3Ding was already part of a horizon of possibilities for us to be in-the-world through such being.

What makes the 3Ding of Second Life rather striking to the new Second Life user is the fact that the capacity to 3D is something one usually associates with one’s direct involvement in the world—by “direct,” we mean without the help of technology. For instance, in Second Life, one’s avatar can walk around a virtual house to reveal some of its sides while hiding others, in an inter-referring matrix mimicking the one through which “real world” experiences are interpreted and given meanings. That is, 3D virtual worlds have this peculiarity of organizing their data in a way reminiscent of the referential systems we are used to coping with “offline,” with the 3D avatar one uses to navigate in-world as the apparent node for the directionality of the online equipment being “lined up.” And for the phenomenologist, it is precisely because an object presents itself to a range of possible views that it is an object (Merleau-Ponty 1945). Likewise, while in a virtual world, users will encounter objects whose partial aspect they will unconsciously complete by referring to an already-known, offline network of meaningful relations (i.e., Heidegger’s “referential whole”). The partiality of the objects encountered (from the 3D avatar’s perspective) seems to reinforce the user’s feeling to be “there”; it provides a feeling of “facticity.” That is, it reinforces the feeling of presence. The conclusion of this phenomenological reduction is in line with Slater et al. (2009) assertion, according to which, for presence to take place in a 3D medium, there is a need for “a level of immersion that permits the generation of images that are plausible in comparison to the probability distribution over images of natural scenes” (Slater et al. 2009).

In this section, both a Cartesianist and a phenomenological interpretation of “presence” and of “being-in-a-virtual-world” were proposed. During this project, an exploratory fieldwork was conducted in Second Life to help us decipher which lens, of the Cartesianist or phenomenological one, is more appropriate to explain the phenomenon of “presence” and the concept of “virtual world.” This fieldwork will be described in the next section.

Fieldwork

Six focus groups were conducted in Second Life, with two objectives in mind: collect data about the users’ perception of this online virtual world and gather opinion on the notion of “being present in Second Life.” Prior to conducting qualitative research in-world, the authors were well-versed in “real world” focus group methodologies, having significant past experience in the domain as both academic marketing researchers and market research practitioners. Before starting this fieldwork, both of the authors spent a significant time in Second Life getting acquainted with the medium. One of the authors participated in several marketing campaigns in Second Life in the 2 years preceding the fieldwork, which allowed him to spend overall between 600 and 800 h in-world, hence to acquire a rather exhaustive knowledge of the medium.

To ensure that the methodologies used for “real world” focus groups would be properly adapted to Second Life’s highly technical context, a market research company with a significant presence in-world, Repères, shared its expertise and experience with the authors, especially during the recruitment phases. The very first focus group was conducted on Repères’ virtual land in Second Life.

Overall, six focus groups were conducted in Second Life, with a total of 38 participants. Keeping track of what was being said and by who revealed to be much more difficult in a 3D online environment, as it is not easy to identify which avatar typed which text. Consequently, the authors chose to have a lower number of participants per focus group than it would ideally be the case in a “real world,” offline context. The participants were recruited either directly by Repères itself or by advertising the event 1 week in advance on Second Life’s online “coming events” website. Efforts were made by the authors to adopt a strict protocol, both for the recruitment of the participants and while conducting the focus groups that were held in-world (e.g., consent forms were sent in-world to the participants prior to each focus group, the participants were briefed on the researchers’ “real world” background, and a focus group guide was developed by the researchers prior to each session). To qualify as a participant, the owner of an avatar had to have an in-world “age” of at least 2 months (the age of an avatar is public information and can easily be accessed by checking the avatar’s profile in Second Life) (Fig. 1).

Of the six focus groups, five were conducted via the “text” system that allows the Second Life users to chat in-world, by typing words on their keyboard. One focus group was conducted via Second Life’s “voice” system, allowing the participants to use their PC’s microphone to communicate. As the “voice” feature revealed to be hard to use for many participants, the method was abandoned after a first attempt. To thank them for their contribution, each of the participants received L$2,000. The topics addressed during the focus groups covered a wide range of issues, among which: the participants’ reasons for having joined and still using Second Life; the importance given by the participants to their avatar’s appearance in-world; the importance of keeping their “real world” and in-world personae separate; the immersive nature of Second Life; the future they envisioned for this type of 3D technology; and their social life in the medium. The last focus group to be conducted focused exclusively on the issue: “For you, what does it mean to be ‘present’ in-world?” The length of the focus groups ranged from 75 min to 1 h and 45 min.

Analysis of the focus groups conducted in-world

Multiple identities, one care

Based on the results of the exploratory focus groups we conducted in-world, it appears that Second Life users rarely want total transparency or isomorphism between their virtual world and their offline world—this for different reasons. To begin with, as mentioned by a focus group participant, multi-tasking may become a challenge if there was an exact isomorphism between “real life” and “Second Life”:

Participant 1: Transparency would stop you from multi-tasking. You would only be able to “do SL” at any moment that you were logged into SL. Eating, drinking, talking to someone else in your room… all impossible if SL is transparent.

In addition, such “transparency” would remove a layer of anonymity, as explained by the following focus group participant:

Participant 2: I think people want control over the transparency from moment to moment. If it were permanently transparent, it would be like having a spy camera at your desk. No one really wants that, even if they think so (…) I doubt anyone would use it if it were available. When you drink your coffee or scratch or whatever, who wants that transmitted into SL?

More than transparency, having a multiplicity of identities is of significant importance to many Second Life users: It is not uncommon for a user to have multiple avatars, and about half of the participants admitted to having more than one active avatar in Second Life. Users often have different avatars for different in-world projects, for different ways of being involved in the world, of being “beyond of themselves”: going to in-world clubs, participating in online chats, meeting in-world friends they know offline, expressing different moods, or representing different facets of their personality. This presents both a challenge and an opportunity for the researcher who wants to conduct focus groups in-world. A challenge because the borders of identity become more blurred. But at the same time, having users “wear” different avatars fitting different types of identity may represent an opportunity for the qualitative researcher, as this might be considered a new set of “rich” data worth collecting and interpreting. It also be noted that, if the concept of identity becomes harder to define since the inception of online virtual worlds, most users interviewed in Second Life still maintain some coherence in their “care,” that is, the essential unity that makes their structure as a human being:

Participant 3: I don’t bother with the separation [between real life and Second Life]. And instead of trying to be a different “person” in RL and SL, I decided to be a better person overall in both, since we are the same.

Participant 4: Even though all different, all my avatars are “me”.

Participant 3: My avatars are extensions of my real self, and I make no distinction. It would be pretty impossible to do otherwise. I’ve always treated them as an extension of my real self… A multiplicity of identities.

There are noticeable differences though in the way people “act on the world” when using Second Life. For some, the new facticity encountered in a virtual world has profoundly affected their way of acting in the world, both online and offline:

Participant 3: You know the saying how owners tend to resemble their pets or vice versa? If not physically, then in personality traits. People tend to start resembling their avatars or vice versa over time…

Participant 5: My avatar destroyed and overwhelmed my RL self. I completely edited my RL [real life] personhood! For the better actually… I have become able to properly define what I don’t want - in my body, in my mind, in my behavior, and alter it. Positively and negatively. SL is a tool of self-reflection (…) I had a [name of avatar] in 1993 [in a different game]. “She” took over. People who remember the [name of avatar] from 20 years ago say it is scary as hell, the way I now talk, the way I dress, the way I have sex [in real life].

For others, the virtual life experience has had little or no effect on their way of acting on the world:

Participant 3: I represent myself in a virtual world exactly as I am in RL, and that tend to break other people’s immersion of fantasy in here. I’m not playing a part other than myself.

According to Heidegger, dread opens up to the person the opportunity to freely exercise its power-to-be on the world in which it was thrown. To dwell more authentically “in” it, virtual worlds such as Second Life allow people to find new ways of getting attuned with the world: Based on the comments above, for some, Second Life has allowed for a new “attunement”—a more authentic one, from an Heideggerian point of view: Feeling less stuck in the facticity of everyday life, in a one and only social identity, Second Life users are more capable of defining who they are, that is, how they can and want to act on the world and relate to other Daseins.

Presence in Second Life

The focus groups conducted during this project confirm that, to be used extensively, a virtual world must lose its conspicuous dimension. To quote Heidegger (1962, p. 99), “it must withdraw in order to be ready-to-hand quite authentically.” Most of the interviewed participants declared that, whenever the hardware or the software behind the in-world experience is brought at the conscious level, the experience is quickly interrupted:

Participant 5: SL is all about suspension of disbelief, when you stop believing that SL is not RL. And to my shock only a very small percentage of people “get” this, probably because of the complex interface.

Participant 6: When I have to think of my keyboard, or when I have to wait one full second for my avatar to respond to my commands, it becomes extremely frustrating.

Participant 7: I think the small details probably help [us] the most [feel “present” in SL]…the clouds that slowly move, things that act the same in SL as they would in RL [real life], no matter how mundane. They help the immersion, because your brain ignores them, rather than notices them due to acting unexpectedly.

Participant 8: When this happens, for instance when you have lag you don’t feel in it anymore, it puts your mind away of what you wanted to do in-world.

Participant 6: Lag, it’s like having a broken toy, like a toy truck with only three wheels. You are better off throwing it away….

Participant 8: You just want to turn off the whole thing [when there is lag]! You will log in again when the bandwidth is higher or something.

Participant 4: I get frustrated [with lag], so my engagement with it decreases

Participant 9: Lag… that is disengaging

This metaphor given by a participant of Second Life being like a “broken toy” when lag occurs is reminiscent of Heidegger’s example of the blind man’s cane: when affordances decrease, severing occurs: What was near becomes far; and fallenness is negatively affected by the resulting break-down.

However, and in a rather counterintuitive manner, for some users, lag results in more engagement, more “fallenness”—hence more felt presence:

Participant 10: Sure, the “lag monster” may get at us… But it’s how we handle it that is the thing.

Participant 11: Lag has just become a way of life.

Participant 12: As I work [as a dancer] in club venues, [lag] acutely becomes something empowering… to be there and have fun despite lag!

That is, for some, the process of struggling to de-severe (and the challenge associated with it) is engaging enough for presence to be felt.The fact that Second Life not only is a virtual world but an online virtual world (i.e., a virtual world with a social dimension) also seems to contribute to the felt feeling of presence (or social presence):

Participant 3: Being present has taken on an interesting meaning in the digital age. Being “present”, in a virtual world like SL, is a matter of perception of attention given to another.

Participant 5: I am sad so much of SL is empty off late. I feel less “there” than before.

The notion of “passive social presence” (Lombard et al. 2009), that is, knowing that other Daseins are “there” too, acting on the world, was also mentioned during the focus groups:

Participant 13: I think it is knowing that somebody is there that makes me feel “present”, even if you don’t necessarily want to interact with them.

Participant 14: Mystery Science Theater makes me feel totally immersed. If you have never seen, it it’s about a dude and a couple robots watching old movies and making fun of them. There is usually a bunch of other people there watching the show. And I just sit there and watch the show. There is nothing more real than my experience there.

Virtual worlds are challenging users’ commonsensical worldview

All of the participants to the focus groups we conducted had at least 3 months of “existence” in Second Life. And some of them had been using the medium for several years (for one of them, since 2004). For the great majority of them, experiencing virtuality had provided them with an opportunity—even a necessity—to question commonsensical notions that they used to take for granted, among which: What does “real” means, how to define “the self” and “others.” As an illustration, one of the participants felt compelled to rethink the separation he used to take for granted between the “real” and the “virtual” after facing the fact that the two can get intertwined:

Participant 5: In fact I was whipped in SL and showed my spouse the red welts on my back. Pure hypnotic autosuggestion…

None of the participants interviewed during the focus groups seemed to be puzzled by questions such as “what does ‘real’ mean to you,” even though they would answer such questions in differing ways. Some have come up with a rather idealistic (in the berkeleyan tradition) ontological explanation:

Participant 3: “Real” is a construct of the mind. Plain and simple.

Participant 15: I don’t believe in “real” or “virtual”, I just believe in… me.

Participant 16: If your mind thinks it’s real, it is.

Some others have put aside the notion of “real” and “virtual,” concluding (in a rather Heideggerian way) that if they could act on the world, then there is a word: representing it, be as 3D grid or a parallel world, is optional if not pointless:

Participant 17: I am working on a fund raiser in SL right now that raised $20,000 US$ last year in this one event… so SL is “real” in that it’s a platform for achieving things of that proportion.

Participant 18: What makes SL real to me? Process. Building and making, being a creative producer.

Discussion and conclusion

“Scientific theory is necessarily based on certain philosophical assumptions that define the foundations on which that science is built,” asserted Lehar (1999, p. 122), adding: “however, the philosophical underpinnings are not always apparent in mature sciences, where the correct philosophical groundwork has been established for so long that alternative philosophies appear too absurd for serious consideration” (Lehar 1999, p. 122). In the same vein, Boellstorff (2008) recently noted the increasing irrelevance of Cartesianism in the Social Sciences by pointing that “between Plato’s time and our own, a reversal has taken place with regard to dominant Western understandings of what is real: we now presume that nonphysical worlds are ontologically subsequent to physical ones. One intriguing possibility is that, with the emergence of new techno-social forms like virtual worlds, Neo-platonist notions of the virtual might reappear” (Boellstorff 2008, p. 34).

In this paper, it has been advanced that Western societies’ implicit philosophical underpinnings—heavily influenced by Cartesianism—have limited so far our understanding of virtual worlds. By bringing into the discussion an alternative paradigm (namely, Heideggerian phenomenology), our goal with this exploratory project was to challenge the implicit Cartesian bias of which some have fallen victim when conceptualizing and evaluating online virtual worlds. Such bias, we believe, has led to some unorthodox research methodologies (e.g., in-world focus groups conducted as if they were “real world” ones) and to truncated ways of evaluating this new medium.

Instead of evaluating an online virtual world based on how closely it replicates an offline environment, we suggest that any evaluation of this new medium be based on its readiness-to-hand (i.e., its inconspicuousness and the fluency of the user experience when using the medium), its fallenness (i.e., the level of existential immersion it offers to its users), and its potential to offer multiple existentialities to its users (i.e., its capacity to allow users to handle different projects or to facilitate the expression of different personalities at different times in the medium). Such phenomenological evaluation, we believe, will allow us to evaluate an online virtual world on more dimensions that the ones that can be used when evaluating an online virtual world from a mere Cartesian perspective.

Even though exploratory, this study contributes to the knowledge of virtual worlds by attempting to think out of the Cartesian box, that is, to conceptualize virtual worlds in a way that alleviates the confusion the very concept of virtuality often raises in a Cartesian mind.

The immersive aspect of virtual worlds was probably not what Heidegger had in mind though when he referred to technology as “the distanceless” (Heidegger 1977). For Heidegger, the authenticity of dwelling, of “inhabiting” a place, was being destroyed by the spread of modern technology and its ability to shrink space. Interestingly, the technology of virtual worlds, because of the opportunity it offers to its users to act more authentically, may lead to a renewed opportunity to “dwell.” Such opportunity and its associated authenticity, we believe, can be leveraged by researchers conducting in-world focus groups. For instance, researchers would be well-advised to use this new possibility to ask their in-world focus group participants to generate new, rich self-expressive data: Not mere verbal ones, but 3D ones. One may imagine for instance a focus group moderator asking the participants to create in 3D an object representing their feelings toward a company or product being discussed.

Other possibilities exist to leverage the true potentials of online virtual worlds. For instance, as most Second Life users also possess several outfits to dress their in-world avatar(s), the moderator of a focus group could ask the participants to choose in their virtual wardrobe the outfit that most accurately represents their feelings toward the topic of the discussion. Given the facticity of the “real world,” collecting this type of visual and vivid data is hardly possible in a regular (non-SL) focus group (as participants cannot change their offline clothing with the mere click of a mouse).

Limitations

This exploratory project has various limitations, both at the conceptual and empirical levels. Conceptually, due to space constraint, the intricacies and subtleties of Heidegger’s work on phenomenology—over a period of half-a-century—had to be summarized and simplified. Short of making the reader fully familiar with phenomenology, the main objective of the review section allocated to phenomenology was to challenge the reader’s everyday worldview, by questioning the apparent commonsensicality of the Cartesian perspective. At the empirical level, this study originated in only six focus groups. Further experiential groups would need to be conducted to amass more data.

Directions for future research

For the present research, the “real” lives of the individuals manipulating avatars in Second Life were not studied. This weakness, unfortunately, is shared by all academic studies published so far on the topic. Another weakness that this research shares with its predecessors is its narrowness, given that only the medium Second Life has been the object of the present investigation. By conducting all their fieldwork in the same medium, researchers run the risk of obtaining contextual findings nonapplicable to other, future media. Beside addressing these two shortcomings, priority might also be given in future research to cross-cultural studies: Not only is this area of research untouched, but the similarities between Eastern cultures and Heideggerian phenomenology may suggest that the perception of “presence” in virtual worlds by other cultures (e.g., in Asia) may be significantly different from the Western one. Last but not least, if some suggestions have been made in this paper on how to leverage in focus groups the self-expressive potentials of virtual worlds, research still has to be conducted on what the protocols of those virtual focus groups should be.
